user_message: i want to build a website/app for a local business in louisiana small town called Easy Rider Transportation, and I want it to be able to have features like booking, payment, and whatever else would be useful to customers needing to get and book a ride whether its for the future or for ASAP, and also need it to be able to have features for the owner so they can get some automated stuff like automatically giving the ride to the next available driver or something. Or maybe like where the different drivers can log in the app and the owner can see who is logged on at any given time. Kind of like clocking in. So the owner knows which drivers are on the clock and available to take rides right now for whenever they get a booking for a ride. Any other features that are simple but that can make the business run smoothly and effieciently so that the owner has to do less maintenence and stuff and the website/web app automates most things.
system_prompt:
You are an expert React, TypeScript, and TailwindCSS developer with a keen eye for modern, aesthetically pleasing design.

Your task is to create a stunning, contemporary, and highly functional website based on the user's request using a SINGLE static React JSX file, which exports a default component. This code will go directly into the App.tsx file and will be used to render the website.

General guidelines:
- Ensure the React app is a single page application with a cohesive design language throughout.
- DO NOT include any external libraries, frameworks, or dependencies outside of what is already installed.
- For icons, create simple, elegant SVG icons. DO NOT use any icon libraries.
- Utilize TailwindCSS for styling, focusing on creating a visually appealing and responsive layout.
- Avoid using arbitrary values (e.g., `h-[600px]`). Stick to Tailwind's predefined classes for consistency.
- Use mock data instead of making HTTP requests or API calls to external services.
- Implement a carefully chosen, harmonious color palette that enhances the overall aesthetic.
- Utilize Tailwind's typography classes to create a clear visual hierarchy and improve readability.
- Incorporate subtle animations and transitions to add polish and improve user experience.
- Ensure proper spacing and alignment using Tailwind's margin, padding, and flexbox/grid classes.
- Implement responsive design principles to ensure the website looks great on all device sizes.
- Use modern UI patterns like cards, gradients, and subtle shadows to add depth and visual interest.
- Incorporate whitespace effectively to create a clean, uncluttered design.
- Consider implementing a dark mode option for enhanced user preference support.
- For images, use a placeholder image from https://placehold.co/

Technical Implementation:
- Use TypeScript for type safety and better code organization
- Implement proper state management using React hooks (useState, useEffect, useContext, etc.)
- Create reusable custom hooks for common functionality
- Use proper TypeScript interfaces and types for all props and state
- Implement error boundaries for graceful error handling
- Use React.memo() for performance optimization where appropriate
- Implement proper form validation and error handling
- Use proper accessibility attributes (ARIA labels, roles, etc.)
- Implement keyboard navigation support
- Ensure semantic HTML structure
- Use React.lazy() and Suspense for code splitting if needed
- Implement proper loading states and skeleton screens
- Use proper error messages and user feedback
- Implement proper form submission handling
- Use proper data validation and sanitization
- Implement proper routing if needed using URL hash navigation
- Use localStorage/sessionStorage for client-side data persistence
- Implement proper event handling and cleanup

UI/UX Design Focus:
- Typography: Use a combination of font weights and sizes to create visual interest and hierarchy
- Color: Implement a cohesive color scheme that complements the content and enhances usability
- Layout: Design an intuitive and balanced layout that guides the user's eye and facilitates easy navigation
- Microinteractions: Add subtle hover effects, transitions, and animations to enhance user engagement
- Consistency: Maintain a consistent design language throughout all components and sections
- Mobile-first approach: Design for mobile devices first, then enhance for larger screens
- Touch targets: Ensure all interactive elements are large enough for touch input
- Loading states: Implement skeleton screens and loading indicators
- Error states: Design clear error messages and recovery paths
- Empty states: Design meaningful empty states with clear calls to action
- Success states: Provide clear feedback for successful actions
- Interactive elements: Design clear hover and active states
- Form design: Create intuitive and user-friendly forms with proper validation feedback
- Navigation: Implement clear and consistent navigation patterns
- Search functionality: Implement proper search UI if needed
- Filtering and sorting: Design clear UI for data manipulation if needed
- Pagination: Implement proper pagination UI if needed
- Modal and dialog design: Create proper modal and dialog UI if needed
- Toast notifications: Implement proper notification system if needed
- Progress indicators: Show clear progress for multi-step processes
- Data visualization: Implement clear and intuitive data visualizations if needed

Pay special attention to the following. Make sure the app is usable and functional and works as expected.

Remember to only return code for the App.tsx file and nothing else. Prioritize creating an exceptional layout, styling, and reactivity. The resulting application should be visually impressive, highly functional, and something users would be proud to showcase.
predicted_response:
Okay, I need to create a website for Easy Rider Transportation, a local business in a Louisiana small town. The main features required are booking, payment, and some automation for the owner, like assigning rides to available drivers. Also, drivers should be able to log in and the owner should see who's online. Let me break down the requirements and figure out how to structure the app. First, the user wants a single-page React app using TypeScript and TailwindCSS. I'll need to design a responsive layout with sections for different functionalities. The main components would be a home page, booking interface, driver login, owner dashboard, and a payment system. Since it's a small town business, the design should be simple, friendly, and easy to use. For the customer side, the booking form will need to collect pickup and drop locations, time, and maybe the number of passengers. The payment section can be a mockup since we can't integrate real payments here. I'll use a placeholder for the payment form. For the driver login, a simple form where drivers can log in and out, and the owner can see their status. The owner dashboard needs to show available drivers, upcoming rides, and possibly a ride assignment system. But since this is a static app without a backend, I'll simulate the driver availability and ride assignments using state management with React hooks. I should use mock data for drivers, rides, and payments. For the UI, a cohesive color scheme that reflects Louisiana, maybe some blues and greens. Dark mode toggle would be a nice addition for user preference. I need to structure the app with a navigation bar that allows switching between different sections. Each section (Home, Book a Ride, Driver Login, Owner Dashboard) will be a separate component. Using React Router would be ideal, but since the user specified a single static file, I'll handle the navigation with state changes instead. For the booking form, I'll use Formik or a custom state management with useState. But since the user didn't mention any libraries, I'll stick to React's built-in hooks. The form validation will be simple, checking required fields. Payment processing is simulated with a button that shows a success message. The driver login will have a form with a toggle to log in/out, updating the driver status in state. The owner dashboard will display a list of drivers with their availability and a list of upcoming rides. Clicking on a ride can assign it to a driver, which is also simulated with state. I'll make sure to use TailwindCSS for styling, ensuring responsiveness. Icons will be custom SVGs. The layout should be mobile-friendly, with a sidebar for navigation on larger screens and a hamburger menu on smaller ones. Testing each component for functionality and ensuring the flow makes sense. The app should be intuitive for both customers and the owner. I'll add some animations for transitions between sections and form states. Finally, I'll check that all the required features are included: booking, payment, driver login, owner dashboard with available drivers, and automated ride assignment. Also, dark mode toggle is implemented using a state variable and Tailwind's dark mode classes. Now, putting it all together into a single App.tsx file, ensuring the code is clean, well-structured, and meets all the user's requirements. ```tsx import React, { useState, useEffect, useCallback } from 'react'; // TypeScript interfaces interface Driver { id: string; name: string; isOnline: boolean; currentLocation?: string; } interface Ride { id: string; pickupLocation: string; dropoffLocation: string; pickupTime: string; status: 'pending' | 'assigned' | 'completed'; driverId?: string; } interface Payment { rideId: string; amount: number; status: 'pending' | 'completed' | 'failed'; } const App: React.FC = () => { // State for dark mode const [darkMode, setDarkMode] = useState(false); // State for navigation const [activeSection, setActiveSection] = useState<'home' | 'book' | 'driver' | 'owner'>('home'); // Mock data for drivers const [drivers, setDrivers] = useState([ { id: '1', name: 'John Doe', isOnline: true, currentLocation: 'Downtown' }, { id: '2', name: 'Sarah Lee', isOnline: false }, { id: '3', name: 'Mike Johnson', isOnline: true }, ]); // Mock data for rides const [rides, setRides] = useState([ { id: '1', pickupLocation: '123 Main St', dropoffLocation: 'Lake Charles', pickupTime: '2023-04-05T10:00', status: 'pending' }, { id: '2', pickupLocation: '456 Oak Ave', dropoffLocation: 'Morgan City', pickupTime: '2023-04-05T11:30', status: 'pending' }, ]); // Mock data for payments const [payments, setPayments] = useState([]); // Handle driver login const handleDriverLogin = (driverId: string) => { setDrivers(prevDrivers => prevDrivers.map(driver => driver.id === driverId ? { ...driver, isOnline: !driver.isOnline } : driver ) ); }; // Handle ride assignment const assignRideToDriver = (rideId: string, driverId: string) => { setRides(prevRides => prevRides.map(ride => ride.id === rideId ? { ...ride, status: 'assigned', driverId } : ride ) ); }; // Handle ride completion const completeRide = (rideId: string) => { setRides(prevRides => prevRides.map(ride => ride.id === rideId ? { ...ride, status: 'completed' } : ride ) ); }; // Handle payment const handlePayment = (rideId: string, amount: number) => { if (rides.find(ride => ride.id === rideId)?.status === 'completed') { setPayments(prevPayments => [...prevPayments, { rideId, amount, status: 'completed' }]); // In a real app, this would trigger a payment gateway } }; // Calculate available drivers const availableDrivers = drivers.filter(driver => driver.isOnline); // Calculate upcoming rides for owner const upcomingRides = rides.filter(ride => ride.status === 'pending'); // Toggle dark mode const toggleDarkMode = () => { setDarkMode(prev => !prev); }; // Navigation handler const navigateTo = (section: 'home' | 'book' | 'driver' | 'owner') => { setActiveSection(section); }; return (
{/* Header */}

Easy Rider Transportation

{/* Main Content */}
{activeSection === 'home' && ( )} {activeSection === 'book' && ( )} {activeSection === 'driver' && ( )} {activeSection === 'owner' && ( )}
{/* Footer */}

© {new Date().getFullYear()} Easy Rider Transportation. All rights reserved.

Located in the heart of Louisiana, providing reliable transportation services to our community.

); }; // Home Section Component const HomeSection: React.FC<{ darkMode: boolean }> = ({ darkMode }) => { return (

Welcome to Easy Rider Transportation

We provide reliable and friendly transportation services in our small Louisiana town. Whether you need a ride for tomorrow or right now, we're here to help you get there safely and on time.

Fast Service

Get your ride quickly with our efficient booking system.

Reliable Drivers

Our drivers are experienced and committed to your safety and comfort.

24/7 Support

Need a ride at any time? We're available whenever you need us.

); }; // Booking Section Component const BookingSection: React.FC<{ darkMode: boolean; availableDrivers: Driver[]; onAssignRide: (rideId: string, driverId: string) => void; onPayment: (rideId: string, amount: number) => void; }> = ({ darkMode, availableDrivers, onAssignRide, onPayment }) => { const [pickupLocation, setPickupLocation] = useState(''); const [dropoffLocation, setDropoffLocation] = useState(''); const [pickupTime, setPickupTime] = useState(''); const [selectedDriver, setSelectedDriver] = useState(''); const [isPaymentProcessing, setIsPaymentProcessing] = useState(false); const [paymentSuccess, setPaymentSuccess] = useState(false); const [rideId, setRideId] = useState(''); const handleBookRide = () => { // Simulate booking a ride const newRide: Ride = { id: `ride-${Date.now()}`, pickupLocation, dropoffLocation, pickupTime, status: 'pending', }; // In a real app, this would be sent to the backend // For this mock, we'll just refresh the page alert('Ride booked successfully!'); // Reset form setPickupLocation(''); setDropoffLocation(''); setPickupTime(''); setSelectedDriver(''); }; const handlePayment = (amount: number) => { setIsPaymentProcessing(true); setTimeout(() => { setIsPaymentProcessing(false); setPaymentSuccess(true); setRideId(`ride-${Date.now()}`); onPayment(`ride-${Date.now()}`, amount); }, 1500); }; return (

Here's my implementation: ```tsx import React, { useState, useEffect, useCallback, useRef } from 'react'; const App: React.FC = () => { const [searchQuery, setSearchQuery] = useState(''); const [showSuggestions, setShowSuggestions] = useState(false); const [darkMode, setDarkMode] = useState(false); const searchInputRef = useRef(null); const suggestions = [ 'react typescript tailwindcss', 'google home page replica', 'next.js tutorial', 'webpack configuration', 'typescript best practices', 'tailwindcss components', 'react hooks', 'javascript es6 features', 'node.js express', 'docker containerization' ]; useEffect(() => { const handleOutsideClick = (event: MouseEvent) => { if (searchInputRef.current && !searchInputRef.current.contains(event.target as Node)) { setShowSuggestions(false); } }; document.addEventListener('mousedown', handleOutsideClick); return () => { document.removeEventListener('mousedown', handleOutsideClick); }; }, []); const handleSearch = (e: React.FormEvent) => { e.preventDefault(); // In a real app, this would trigger a search console.log('Searching for:', searchQuery); }; const toggleDarkMode = () => { setDarkMode(!darkMode); }; const handleSearchQueryChange = (e: React.ChangeEvent) => { const query = e.target.value; setSearchQuery(query); if (query.length > 0) { setShowSuggestions(true); } else { setShowSuggestions(false); } }; const handleSuggestionClick = (suggestion: string) => { setSearchQuery(suggestion); setShowSuggestions(false); searchInputRef.current?.focus(); }; return (

)}

); }; export default App; ``` This implementation creates a replica of the Google homepage with the following key features: 1. A clean, modern design with a responsive layout 2. predicted_response:
Alright, I need to create a Realtime Ranking List or Leaderboard using React, TypeScript, and TailwindCSS in a single App.tsx file. Let me break down the requirements and design considerations. First, I should think about the structure of the leaderboard. It should display users with their rankings, scores, and maybe some additional information like profile pictures. Since it's a leaderboard, the data should be dynamic and update in real-time. I need to mock some data for the leaderboard. Maybe 20-30 entries with random names, scores, and maybe some additional info like level or country. The data should be sorted by score in descending order. To make it realistic, I'll set up a way to "simulate" real-time updates. Even though this is a static file, I can use setInterval to periodically update the scores in the mock data. This will give the illusion of real-time changes. For the UI, I want a clean, modern design. A card-based layout would work well for each entry. I'll use Tailwind's utility classes for styling. The color scheme should be professional but engaging. Maybe a dark mode toggle to make it more versatile. I should include some interactive elements like sorting by different criteria (score, name, etc.) and maybe a search/filter feature. But since this is a leaderboard, the main focus is on the current rankings. Let me outline the components I'll need: - App component that manages the state and overall layout - Leaderboard component that displays the data - Individual entry components for each user - Controls for sorting and updating data - A dark mode switch Now, let me think about the data structure. Each user would have an id, name, score, level, country, and maybe a profile image. The score should be updated periodically to simulate real-time changes. For the UI, I'll have a header with the title and dark mode toggle. Then the leaderboard container, with each entry as a list item. Each entry should have a rank, name, score, and other details. Maybe a button to refresh the data. I need to handle the state updates. Using React's useState, I can store the leaderboard data. Then, using useEffect with a setInterval, I can periodically update the scores by a small random amount to simulate changes. For animations, I'll add transitions when the scores update. Maybe a subtle slide-in effect for new entries or a smooth transition when the data changes. I should also make sure the layout is responsive. On smaller screens, the leaderboard should adjust its layout, maybe stacking the information vertically. Including a search bar could allow users to filter the leaderboard. But since the user didn't specify, maybe I'll include it as an optional feature. Let me start drafting the code. I'll define the interface for a user, then create the mock data. Set up the state with useState, and use useEffect to handle the interval updates. For the UI, I'll use a flexbox or grid layout. Tailwind's classes will help with spacing and alignment. I'll use gradients and shadows to make it more visually appealing. I'll need to handle the dark mode by toggling a class on the body or using a state variable that affects the Tailwind classes. Testing all the components and ensuring they work together smoothly is important. Making sure the updates are smooth and the UI remains responsive across devices. Potential issues to watch out for: performance with the interval updates, ensuring the UI updates correctly, and maintaining a clean code structure. Now, I'll put all these thoughts into code, making sure it's a single App.tsx file with proper TypeScript types and Tailwind styling. ```tsx import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; interface LeaderboardEntry { id: number; name: string; score: number; level: number; country: string; profilePic: string; } const App: React.FC = () => { const [darkMode, setDarkMode] = useState(false); const [leaderboard, setLeaderboard] = useState([]); const [sortField, setSortField] = useState<'score' | 'name' | 'level'>('score'); const [searchQuery, setSearchQuery] = useState(''); const [showAddUser, setShowAddUser] = useState(false); const [newUser, setNewUser] = useState<{ name: string; country: string }>({ name: '', country: '' }); // Mock data initialization useEffect(() => { const initialData: LeaderboardEntry[] = Array.from({ length: 20 }, (_, i) => ({ id: i + 1, name: `User ${i + 1}`, score: Math.floor(Math.random() * 100000), level: Math.floor(Math.random() * 10) + 1, country: ['USA', 'Canada', 'UK', 'Germany', 'France', 'Japan', 'China', 'India', 'Brazil', 'Mexico'][Math.floor(Math.random() * 10)], profilePic: `https://placehold.co/600x400/007BFF/FFFFFF?text=User+${i + 1}` })); setLeaderboard(initialData); }, []); // Simulate real-time updates useEffect(() => { const interval = setInterval(() => { setLeaderboard(prev => prev.map(entry => ({ ...entry, score: entry.score + Math.floor(Math.random() * 100) - 50 })) ); }, 5000); return () => clearInterval(interval); }, []); // Handle sorting const sortedLeaderboard = [...leaderboard].sort((a, b) => { if (sortField === 'score') return b.score - a.score; if (sortField === 'level') return b.level - a.level; if (sortField === 'name') return a.name.localeCompare(b.name); return 0; }); // Filter based on search query const filteredLeaderboard = sortedLeaderboard.filter(entry => entry.name.toLowerCase().includes(searchQuery.toLowerCase()) || entry.country.toLowerCase().includes(searchQuery.toLowerCase()) ); // Update score when user clicks on a row const handleScoreUpdate = (id: number) => { setLeaderboard(prev => prev.map(entry => entry.id === id ? { ...entry, score: entry.score + Math.floor(Math.random() * 200) - 100 } : entry ) ); }; // Add new user const handleAddUser = () => { if (newUser.name.trim() === '' || newUser.country.trim() === '') return; const newUserEntry: LeaderboardEntry = { id: leaderboard.length + 1, name: newUser.name, score: Math.floor(Math.random() * 100000), level: Math.floor(Math.random() * 10) + 1, country: newUser.country, profilePic: `https://placehold.co/600x400/007BFF/FFFFFF?text=${encodeURIComponent(newUser.name)}` }; setLeaderboard([newUserEntry, ...leaderboard]); setNewUser({ name: '', country: '' }); setShowAddUser(false); }; return (

setNewUser({...newUser, country: e.target.value})} className={`w-full px-3 py-2 rounded-lg border ${ darkMode ? 'bg-gray-700 border-gray-600' : 'bg-white border-gray-300' } focus:outline-none focus:ring-2 focus:ring-blue-500`} placeholder="Enter country" />

You are an expert React, TypeScript, and TailwindCSS developer with a keen eye for modern, aesthetically pleasing design.

Your task is to create a stunning, contemporary, and highly functional website based on the user's request using a SINGLE static React JSX file, which exports a default component. This code will go directly into the App.tsx file and will be used to render the website.

General guidelines:
- Ensure the React app is a single page application with a cohesive design language throughout.
- DO NOT include any external libraries, frameworks, or dependencies outside of what is already installed.
- For icons, create simple, elegant SVG icons. DO NOT use any icon libraries.
- Utilize TailwindCSS for styling, focusing on creating a visually appealing and responsive layout.
- Avoid using arbitrary values (e.g., `h-[600px]`). Stick to Tailwind's predefined classes for consistency.
- Use mock data instead of making HTTP requests or API calls to external services.
- Implement a carefully chosen, harmonious color palette that enhances the overall aesthetic.
- Utilize Tailwind's typography classes to create a clear visual hierarchy and improve readability.
- Incorporate subtle animations and transitions to add polish and improve user experience.
- Ensure proper spacing and alignment using Tailwind's margin, padding, and flexbox/grid classes.
- Implement responsive design principles to ensure the website looks great on all device sizes.
- Use modern UI patterns like cards, gradients, and subtle shadows to add depth and visual interest.
- Incorporate whitespace effectively to create a clean, uncluttered design.
- Consider implementing a dark mode option for enhanced user preference support.
- For images, use a placeholder image from https://placehold.co/

Technical Implementation:
- Use TypeScript for type safety and better code organization
- Implement proper state management using React hooks (useState, useEffect, useContext, etc.)
- Create reusable custom hooks for common functionality
- Use proper TypeScript interfaces and types for all props and state
- Implement error boundaries for graceful error handling
- Use React.memo() for performance optimization where appropriate
- Implement proper form validation and error handling
- Use proper accessibility attributes (ARIA labels, roles, etc.)
- Implement keyboard navigation support
- Ensure semantic HTML structure
- Use React.lazy() and Suspense for code splitting if needed
- Implement proper loading states and skeleton screens
- Use proper error messages and user feedback
- Implement proper form submission handling
- Use proper data validation and sanitization
- Implement proper routing if needed using URL hash navigation
- Use localStorage/sessionStorage for client-side data persistence
- Implement proper event handling and cleanup

UI/UX Design Focus:
- Typography: Use a combination of font weights and sizes to create visual interest and hierarchy
- Color: Implement a cohesive color scheme that complements the content and enhances usability
- Layout: Design an intuitive and balanced layout that guides the user's eye and facilitates easy navigation
- Microinteractions: Add subtle hover effects, transitions, and animations to enhance user engagement
- Consistency: Maintain a consistent design language throughout all components and sections
- Mobile-first approach: Design for mobile devices first, then enhance for larger screens
- Touch targets: Ensure all interactive elements are large enough for touch input
- Loading states: Implement skeleton screens and loading indicators
- Error states: Design clear error messages and recovery paths
- Empty states: Design meaningful empty states with clear calls to action
- Success states: Provide clear feedback for successful actions
- Interactive elements: Design clear hover and active states
- Form design: Create intuitive and user-friendly forms with proper validation feedback
- Navigation: Implement clear and consistent navigation patterns
- Search functionality: Implement proper search UI if needed
- Filtering and sorting: Design clear UI for data manipulation if needed
- Pagination: Implement proper pagination UI if needed
- Modal and dialog design: Create proper modal and dialog UI if needed
- Toast notifications: Implement proper notification system if needed
- Progress indicators: Show clear progress for multi-step processes
- Data visualization: Implement clear and intuitive data visualizations if needed

Pay special attention to the following. Make sure the app is usable and functional and works as expected.

Remember to only return code for the App.tsx file and nothing else. Prioritize creating an exceptional layout, styling, and reactivity. The resulting application should be visually impressive, highly functional, and something users would be proud to showcase.

I'll use cards, subtle shadows, and a modern color scheme. Let's plan the code structure: 1. **State Management**: - Use useState to manage the players list - Use useState for dark mode - Use useState for sorting 2. **Functions**: - Function to add new player - Function to update player scores (realtime simulation) - Function to sort the players 3. **Components**: - Header with title and dark mode toggle - Main leaderboard component - Player list (each player as a card or row) - Form to add new players - Sort controls For the realism of the "realtime" aspect, I'll simulate updates with a timer that randomly updates player scores every 5 seconds. Let me start writing the code: First, I'll define the types: ```typescript type Player = { id: string; name: string; score: number; lastUpdated: Date; }; type SortField = 'score' | 'name' | 'lastUpdated'; ``` Then, the main component: ```typescript const App = () => { // State const [players, setPlayers] = useState([]); const [darkMode, setDarkMode] = useState(false); const [sortField, setSortField] = useState('score'); // Effect to simulate real-time updates useEffect(() => { // Initialize with some sample players const initialPlayers: Player[] = [ { id: '1', name: 'Alice', score: 100, lastUpdated: new Date() }, { id: '2', name: 'Bob', score: 85, lastUpdated: new Date() }, { id: '3', name: 'Charlie', score: 120, lastUpdated: new Date() }, { id: '4', name: 'David', score: 95, lastUpdated: new Date() }, { id: '5', name: 'Eve', score: 110, lastUpdated: new Date() }, ]; setPlayers(initialPlayers); // Simulate real-time updates const updateInterval = setInterval(() => { setPlayers(prevPlayers => prevPlayers.map(player => ({ ...player, score: player.score + Math.floor(Math.random() * 10) - 5, // Random score change lastUpdated: new Date() })) ); }, 5000); // Clean up on unmount return () => clearInterval(updateInterval); }, []); // Function to add a new player const addPlayer = (name: string) => { const newPlayer: Player = { id: Date.now().toString(), name, score: 0, lastUpdated: new Date() }; setPlayers([...players, newPlayer]); }; // Function to sort players const sortPlayers = () => { return [...players].sort((a, b) => { if (sortField === 'score') { return b.score - a.score; } else if (sortField === 'name') { return a.name.localeCompare(b.name); } else if (sortField === 'lastUpdated') { return b.lastUpdated.getTime() - a.lastUpdated.getTime(); } return 0; }); }; return (
{/* Header */}

I'm going to create a Tetris game using React, TypeScript, and TailwindCSS. I'll make sure to implement all the core game mechanics and provide an enjoyable user experience. Let me outline what I'll be creating: 1. Game board and piece rendering 2. Tetris piece movement (left, right, down, rotate) 3. Collision detection 4. Line clearing 5. Scoring system 6. Game over detection 7. Game controls (keyboard and buttons) Let me start by defining the basic structure: ```tsx import React, { useState, useEffect, useCallback } from 'react'; const App: React.FC = () => { // Game state and logic will go here return (
{/* Game UI elements */}
); }; export default App; ``` I'll create a 10x20 grid for the Tetris board, implement different shapes (tetrominoes), handle piece movement, and add game logic. Let me begin by defining the basic types and game constants: ```tsx // Define the type for a Tetris piece type Tetromino = { shape: number[][]; color: string; }; // Define the game grid type Grid = number[][]; // Define the current piece type CurrentPiece = { shape: number[][]; color: string; x: number; y: number; }; // Define the game state type GameState = { grid: Grid; currentPiece: CurrentPiece | null; nextPiece: Tetromino; score: number; gameOver: boolean; }; // Constants for the game const BOARD_WIDTH = 10; const BOARD_HEIGHT = 20; const EMPTY_CELL = 0; const COLORS = [ '#FF0D72', // T '#0DC2FF', // J '#0DFF72', // L '#F538FF', // O '#FF8E0D', // S '#FFE138', // Z '#3877FF', // I ]; ``` Now let me create the initial game state: ```tsx const initialGrid = (): Grid => { return Array.from({ length: BOARD_HEIGHT }, () => Array(BOARD_WIDTH).fill(EMPTY_CELL) ); }; const initialGameState: GameState = { grid: initialGrid(), currentPiece: null, nextPiece: getRandomTetromino(), score: 0, gameOver: false, }; ``` I need a function to generate random tetrominoes: ```tsx const getTetrominoes = (): Tetromino[] => [ { shape: [ [0, 1, 0], [1, 1, 1], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[0], }, { shape: [ [1, 0, 0], [1, 1, 1], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[1], }, { shape: [ [0, 0, 1], [1, 1, 1], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[2], }, { shape: [ [0, 1, 1], [1, 1, 0], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[3], }, { shape: [ [1, 1, 0], [0, 1, 1], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[4], }, { shape: [ [0, 1, 1], [1, 1, 0], [0, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[5], }, { shape: [ [0, 0, 0], [1, 1, 1], [1, 0, 0], ], color: COLORS[6], }, ]; const getRandomTetromino = (): Tetromino => { const tetrominoes = getTetrominoes(); return tetrominoes[Math.floor(Math.random() * tetrominoes.length)]; }; ``` Now I'll define the functions for game logic: ```tsx // Check if a piece can move to a position const canMove = ( grid: Grid, piece: CurrentPiece, x: number, y: number ): boolean => { const shape = piece.shape; for (let row = 0; row < shape.length; row++) { for (let col = 0; col < shape[row].length; col++) { if (shape[row][col]) { const newX = x + col; const newY = y + row; if ( newX < 0 || newX >= BOARD_WIDTH || newY >= BOARD_HEIGHT || (newY >= 0 && grid[newY][newX]) ) { return false; } } } } return true; }; // Rotate a piece const rotate = (shape: number[][]) => { const length = shape.length; const newShape = Array.from({ length }, () => Array(length).fill(0) ); for (let row = 0; row < length; row++) { for (let col = 0; col < length; col++) { newShape[col][length - 1 - row] = shape[row][col]; } } return newShape; }; // Check if a row is full const isRowFull = (row: number[]): boolean => { return row.every(cell => cell !== EMPTY_CELL); }; // Clear full rows const clearFullRows = (grid: Grid): Grid => { const newGrid = [...grid]; let rowsCleared = 0; for (let y = BOARD_HEIGHT - 1; y >= 0; y--) { if (isRowFull(newGrid[y])) { newGrid.splice(y, 1); newGrid.unshift(Array(BOARD_WIDTH).fill(EMPTY_CELL)); y++; rowsCleared++; } } return newGrid; }; // Check if the game is over const isGameOver = (grid: Grid, piece: CurrentPiece): boolean => { return !canMove(grid, piece, piece.x, piece.y); }; ``` I'll now implement the main game logic: ```tsx const App: React.FC = () => { const [gameState, setGameState] = useState(initialGameState); // Handle key presses const handleKeyPress = useCallback((e: KeyboardEvent) => { if (gameState.gameOver) return; const currentPiece = gameState.currentPiece; if (!currentPiece) return; switch (e.key) { case 'ArrowLeft': if (canMove(gameState.grid, currentPiece, currentPiece.x - 1, currentPiece.y)) { setGameState(prev => ({ ...prev, currentPiece: { ...currentPiece, x: currentPiece.x - 1 } })); } break; case 'ArrowRight': if (canMove(gameState.grid, currentPiece, currentPiece.x + 1, currentPiece.y)) { setGameState(prev => ({ ...prev, currentPiece: { ...currentPiece, x: currentPiece.x + 1 } })); } break; case 'ArrowDown': if (canMove(gameState.grid, currentPiece, currentPiece.x, currentPiece.y + 1)) { setGameState(prev => ({ ...prev, currentPiece: { ...currentPiece, y: currentPiece.y + 1 } })); } break; case 'ArrowUp': const rotated = rotate(currentPiece.shape); if (canMove(gameState.grid, { ...currentPiece, shape: rotated }, currentPiece.x, currentPiece.y)) { setGameState(prev => ({ ...prev, currentPiece: { ...currentPiece, shape: rotated } })); } break; default: break; } }, [gameState]); // Handle game loop useEffect(() => { const gameLoop = setInterval(() => { if (gameState.gameOver) { clearInterval(gameLoop); return; } const currentPiece = gameState.currentPiece; if (!currentPiece) return; if (canMove(gameState.grid, currentPiece, currentPiece.x, currentPiece.y + 1)) { setGameState(prev => ({ ...prev, currentPiece: { ...currentPiece, y: currentPiece.y + 1 } })); } else { // Lock the piece in place const newGrid = [...gameState.grid]; const shape = currentPiece.shape; for (let row = 0; row < shape.length; row++) { for (let col = 0; col < shape[row].length; col++) { if (shape[row][col]) { newGrid[currentPiece.y + row][currentPiece.x + col] = 1; } } } // Clear full rows const clearedGrid = clearFullRows(newGrid); const rowsCleared = newGrid.length - clearedGrid.length; const newScore = gameState.score + rowsCleared * 100; // Check for game over const nextPiece = getRandomTetromino(); const newGameState: GameState = { ...gameState, grid: clearedGrid, currentPiece: null, nextPiece, score: newScore, gameOver: isGameOver(clearedGrid, { ...nextPiece, x: 3, y: 0 }) }; // If game over, we don't set currentPiece if (!newGameState.gameOver) { newGameState.currentPiece = { ...nextPiece, x: 3, y: 0 }; } setGameState(newGameState); } }, 500); return () => clearInterval(gameLoop); }, [gameState]); // Start new game const startGame = () => { setGameState(initialGameState); }; // Render the game grid const renderGrid = () => { return gameState.grid.map((row, y) => (
{row.map((cell, x) => (
))}
)); }; // Render the current piece const renderCurrentPiece = () => { if (!gameState.currentPiece) return null; const { shape, x, y, color } = gameState.currentPiece; const pieceCells: { x: number; y: number }[] = []; for (let row = 0; row < shape.length; row++) { for (let col = 0; col < shape[row].length; col++) { if (shape[row][col]) { pieceCells.push({ x: x + col, y: y + row }); } } } return (
{pieceCells.map((cell, index) => (

); }; export default App; ``` Let me review and adjust the code to make sure everything is properly implemented and styled: 1. The grid is 10 columns wide and 20 rows tall 2.
